title: R43168
content: From summer 2013 to 2016, media reports highlighted sexual assault incidents in the U.S. armed services, leading to questions about actions taken by the Department of Defense, the Obama Administration, and Congress. This report provides a detailed timeline of official responses to military sexual assault and legislative actions in the 113th and 114th Congresses. It includes information on the DOD and Obama Administration's actions, congressional initiatives, and related resources. In June 2012, Army Major General Gary S. Patton was appointed as the new director of the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office (SAPRO). In September 2012, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta announced improvements to training and a review of the military training environment to address sexual assault. In December 2012, the DOD released findings showing an increase in unwanted sexual contact at military academies, with the Air Force Academy reporting the largest increase in sexual assaults. Sexual assaults increased at Naval Academy in Annapolis and U.S. Military Academy in West Point. DOD released 2012 Workplace and Gender Relations Survey. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel reviewed decision to overturn sexual assault conviction of Air Force fighter pilot. In November 2012, Colonel Wilkerson was convicted of aggravated sexual assault and sentenced to one year in military prison. Lt. General Franklin overturned the court-martial findings, allowing Wilkerson to be reinstated in the Air Force. Secretary Chuck Hagel called for a review of how sexual assault cases are handled in the military and emphasized the need to create a culture that does not tolerate such behavior. In April 2013, Secretary Hagel announced a review of Article 60 of the UCMJ after an Air Force officer's sexual assault conviction was dismissed. In May 2013, a 24-page memorandum was released regarding DOD's Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Strategy, revealing a 6% increase in reported sexual assaults in FY2012. An anonymous survey suggested as many as 26,000 service members may have experienced unwanted sexual contact. In May 2013, DOD announced new actions to address sexual assault, including holding military commanders accountable for creating respectful environments and establishing a Response Systems Panel for Adult Sexual Assault Crimes. The number of reported sexual assaults in the military increased to an estimated 26,000, with offenses ranging from abusive sexual contact to rape. On May 14, 2013, an Army Sergeant First Class was under investigation for various offenses. The next day, Army Gen. Martin E. Dempsey called sexual assault in the Armed Forces a crisis. President Obama met with military leaders on May 16, 2013, to address the issue. On May 17, 2013, Defense Secretary Hagel and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Army Gen. Dempsey discussed the issue of sexual assault in the U.S. military. Gen. Dempsey highlighted the potential influence of long wars in Iraq and Afghanistan on the rise of sexual assault incidents. Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Walsh, mentioned that alcohol use and lack of respect are common factors in sexual assaults within the Air Force. Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. Walsh stated that lack of respect for women and alcohol use are common factors in sexual assaults within the Air Force. He emphasized that combatting the crisis is his top priority and reviews every reported case of sexual assault. Pentagon announced that DOD's sexual assault prevention staff would be exempt from furloughs to ensure responsive victim care and efficient implementation of policies directed by Secretary Hagel. President Obama addressed misconduct in the military during a commencement speech at the U.S. Naval Academy. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel emphasized the importance of building a culture of respect in the military and condemned sexual harassment and assault as betrayals of trust and oaths. Pentagon officials reaffirmed the commitment to fighting sexual assault by launching the Safe program. The Pentagon launched the Safe HelpRoom at SafeHelpline.org for DOD community members to connect and support each other in a secure online environment. Navy Adm. James A. Winnefeld Jr. outlined plans to combat sexual assault, including investing in trained investigators and providing more assistance to victims. Officials will also study behavioral factors of potential predators. On June 7, 2013, Maj. Gen. Michael T. Harrison was suspended for failing to report a sexual assault allegation. Maj. Gen. Margaret H. Woodward replaced Lt. Col. Jeffrey Krusinski to lead the Air Force Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Woodward previously led an investigation into a sexual assault scandal at Lackland Air Force Base. Defense Secretary Hagel met with the Sexual Assault Response Systems Review Panel to review systems for investigating and prosecuting sexual assault cases in the military. The panel was established in response to a scandal at Lackland Air Force Base. Additionally, Army Gen. Frank J. Grass launched a campaign to combat sexual assault in National Guard units as part of a broader military effort to protect victims. The DOD Inspector General released a report evaluating Military Criminal Investigative Organizations' sexual assault investigations in 2010. Most investigations met investigative standards, with only 11% having significant deficiencies. The Air Force implemented new measures to combat sexual assault, including mandatory discharge for offenders and senior commanders reviewing actions taken on these cases. The Air Force Academy is reviewing survey results on sexual assault, with suggestions for improvement. Secretary of the Navy announced resources for investigators and a new initiative for accountability. The Air Force announced discharge for airmen who commit sexual assaults, with senior commanders reviewing actions taken. As of July 2, 2013, a new Air Force initiative mandates discharge for those who commit sexual assaults, with senior commanders reviewing actions taken. Defense Secretary Hagel announced seven anti-sexual assault initiatives on August 15, 2013, emphasizing a commitment to providing a safe environment. Air Force Col. Alan R. Metzler highlighted the importance of prevention in stopping sexual assault in the military on October 3, 2013. Measures to improve victims' confidence and combat underreporting were also discussed. On November 9, 2013, Army Maj. Gen. Gary S. Patton reported on DOD's recent prevention and awareness successes, leading to a 46% increase in victims reporting sexual assault compared to the previous year. President Obama instructed Defense Secretary Hagel and Chairman Dempsey on December 20, 2013, to continue efforts to improve sexual assault prevention and response, including a full-scale review of progress by December 1, 2014. On January 10, 2014, Army Maj. Gen. Jeffrey J. Snow announced the release of the Annual Report to Congress on Sexual Harassment and Violence at the Military Service Academies for the 2012-13 academic year. The report showed a decrease in sexual assault reports at the U.S. Military Academy and the U.S. Air Force Academy, but an increase at the U.S. Naval Academy. On January 30, 2014, the Response Systems to Adult Sexual Assault Crimes Panel accepted a recommendation for senior military commanders to retain authority for referring these crimes to courts-martial. On May 1, 2014, the DOD released the 2013 Annual Report on Sexual Assault in the Military, revealing 5,061 reports of sexual assault. The period from Oct. 1, 2012, through Sept. 30, 2013, saw a 50 percent increase in reports of sexual assault in the Defense Department, totaling 5,061 cases. More than 70 percent of cases resulted in criminal charges. In July 2014, the DOD collaborated with the Justice Department to enhance training for sexual assault response coordinators and victim advocates. By December 2014, Secretary Hagel released a report on the progress in addressing sexual assault in the military, with directives to strengthen prevention and response programs. Survey data showed a decrease in sexual assaults in FY2014 compared to FY2012, with an estimated 19,000 cases reported. In FY2014, there were fewer sexual assaults reported compared to FY2012, with an estimated 19,000 cases down from 26,000. Secretary Hagel emphasized the need for a personal commitment to end sexual assault in the military. Progress was noted in reducing unwanted sexual contact at military service academies in APY 2013-2014. Experts discussed the issue of underreporting at the Army's Sexual Harassment/Assault Response Program Summit. At the Army's Sexual Harassment/Assault Response Program Summit, Army Maj. Gen. Jeffrey Snow discussed the underreporting of male victims of sexual assault in the military due to shame and fear of ostracization. Recent data shows a significant decrease in sexual assault cases, with estimates indicating 6,000 to 7,000 fewer assaults in 2014 compared to 2012. The 2014 RAND Military Workplace Study reported a decline in unwanted sexual contact for both active duty women and men from 2012 to 2014. In 2014, an estimated 18,900 service members experienced unwanted sexual contact, a decrease from around 26,000 in 2012. Defense Secretary Ash Carter announced various initiatives to address sexual assault in the military, including the appointment of Army Maj. Gen. Camille M. Nichols as director of SAPRO and the release of the Annual Report on Sexual Harassment and Violence at the Military Service Academies for Academic Year 2014-2015. Additionally, a strategy was announced to prevent and respond to sexual assault retaliation within the department. In FY2015, 6,083 service members reported sexual assault, with a rate similar to the previous year. 21% of restricted reports were converted to unrestricted, allowing participation in the military justice process. The Naval Academy hosted a training event to support servicemembers reporting sexual assault. DOD released the 2016 Military Investigation and Justice Experience Survey for servicemembers who have experienced sexual assault. Defense Department officials released the "DOD Plan to Prevent and Respond to Sexual Assault of Military Men" on December 15, 2016, aimed at enhancing outreach and support for servicemembers who have experienced sexual assault. Additionally, on January 23, 2013, the House Armed Services Committee held a hearing on sexual misconduct at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, TX, and on January 25, 2013, H.R. 430, the Protect Our Military Trainees Act, was introduced. H.R. 430, Protect Our Military Trainees Act, introduced to amend the Uniform Code of Military Justice to protect new Armed Forces trainees from sexual advances by instructors. S. 548, Military Sexual Assault Prevention Act of 2013, introduced on March 13, 2013. On March 13, 2013, the Military Sexual Assault Prevention Act of 2013 was introduced to improve the Armed Forces' capabilities to prevent and respond to sexual assault and harassment. Victims of sexual assault in the military testified before a Senate panel, highlighting the broken military justice system and urging Congress to make changes to address pervasive rape, assault, and harassment. In 2000, a Navy servicemember testified about being raped by a higher-ranking officer on a submarine. He expressed shame over how the Navy forced him to leave. A bill was introduced in March 2013 to extend the Physical Disability Board of Review's authority to review separations based on mental conditions, including victims of sexual assault in the military. In April 2013, H.R. 1593, the Sexual Assault Training Oversight and Prevention (STOP) Act, was introduced to improve prevention and response to sexual assault in the Armed Forces. A U.S. senator put a hold on the nomination of Air Force Lt. Gen. Susan Helms, who had overturned a conviction of aggravated sexual assault. On May 7, 2013, legislation was introduced to combat military sexual assault, providing victims with special military lawyers, prohibiting sexual contact between instructors and trainees, and ensuring sexual assault response coordinators are available for National Guard and Reserve members. Another bill was introduced to require Inspector General investigations of retaliatory personnel actions in response to protected communications about sexual assault. The bill introduced to combat military sexual assault required investigations by the Inspector General of the Department of Defense or Department of Homeland Security regarding retaliatory personnel actions in response to protected communications about sexual assault. Gen. Mark Welsh expressed shock at charges against Lt. Col. Jeffrey Krusinski for alleged misconduct. H.R. 1867, the BE SAFE Act of 2013, aimed to address sexual assault in the military by requiring Inspector General investigations of retaliatory actions against whistleblowers. The bill proposed dismissing or dishonorably discharging those found guilty of sexual crimes in the military. The military's justice system may eliminate the five-year statute of limitations for sexual assault cases and expand legal assistance services for victims. Senators questioned Air Force leaders about rising sexual assaults, citing DOD statistics and the arrest of Lt. Col. Jeffrey Krusinski for sexual battery. A House Appropriations Committee hearing on the Air Force budget included testimony from Secretary Michael Donley and General Mark Welsh, with questions about Defense Secretary Hagel's review. On May 14, 2013, a resolution was introduced to establish the "Special Committee on Sexual Assault and Abuse in the Armed Forces," following Defense Secretary Hagel's review of a decision regarding a sexual assault conviction. The committee would have included 19 members appointed by the Speaker and Minority Leader, as well as chairman and ranking members of key committees. Additionally, a bill was introduced to authorize appropriations for FY2014 for military activities of the Department of Defense. The FY2014 NDAA addressed sexual assault in the military by establishing sentencing guidelines for offenders. H.R. 1986 aimed to deploy Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners in Armed Forces units, while H.R. 2002 sought to provide sexual assault victims with special military lawyers. H.R. 2016, Military Justice Improvement Act of 2013, aimed to address sexual assault in the military by requiring immediate action upon receiving reports of sexual-related offenses. This bill was related to other bills such as S. 538, Military Sexual Assault Prevention Act of 2013, and S. 967, Military Justice Improvement Act of 2013. In May 2013, bills were introduced to address sexual assault in the military, including S. 967 which required commanding officers to act immediately on reports of sex-related offenses. Another bill, S. 992, focused on sexual assault prevention and response. Additionally, a House panel passed changes to limit commander discretion in handling rape and assault charges and expand support services for victims. The House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel approved personnel issues in H.R. 1960, the FY2014 NDAA bill, including requiring soldiers considered for sexual assault prevention jobs to undergo behavioral-health evaluations. Army Secretary McHugh announced this at a Senate hearing on the Army's FY 2014 Budget Request. On May 23, 2013, the Better Enforcement for Sexual Assault Free Environments Act of 2013 was introduced to improve the Uniform Code of Military Justice regarding sex-related offenses. On June 4, 2013, military leaders admitted neglecting the "epidemic" of sexual abuse in the ranks during a Senate hearing. Army Gen. Martin Dempsey highlighted competing demands as a factor. Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Army Gen. Martin Dempsey cited the challenges of fighting wars in Iraq and Afghanistan as a reason for inadequate monitoring. Service Chiefs supported tougher actions against offenders and more support for victims of military sexual assault. They opposed a proposal to remove unit commanders' legal power in major criminal cases. Gen. Ray Odierno emphasized the importance of commanders' authority in military justice for discipline and culture change. S. 1092 was introduced on June 4, 2013, to amend Title. The House Armed Services Committee passed H.R. 1960, the NDAA for FY2014, allowing victims of sexual assault to apply for a permanent change of station or unit transfer. It also authorizes the Secretary of Defense to inform commanders of their authority to remove or temporarily reassign service members who are alleged perpetrators of sexual assault. The bill requires the provision of victims' counsels, qualified lawyers in each service, to provide legal assistance to victims of sex-related offenses. The FY14 NDAA includes provisions to protect victims of sexual assault in the Armed Forces as protected communications under military whistle-blower laws, encouraging more victims to report assaults. H.R. 2397, "Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2014," was introduced to address the pervasive problem of sexual assault in the Armed Forces. The FY14 NDAA includes measures to address sexual assault in the military, with a focus on cultural change and increased funding for prevention and victim counseling programs. S. 1197, NDAA for Fiscal Year 2014, introduced in the Senate, included provisions for military activities, construction, and defense activities funding. The FY14 NDAA includes measures to address sexual assault in the military, with a focus on cultural change and increased funding for prevention and victim counseling programs. H.R. 1864, a bill related to sexual assault prevention and response, was passed in the House. Army Gen. Martin E. Dempsey and Navy Adm. James A. Winnefeld Jr. testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee. James A. Winnefeld Jr., the vice chairman, emphasized the importance of commanders retaining responsibility for prosecuting service members accused of sexual assault to maintain good order and discipline. Legislation was introduced to authorize the suspension of pay for violent offenders in the military pending trial for sex-related or capital offenses. An amendment was passed to provide funds for identifying and correcting records of individuals separated from the military after reporting a sexual assault. On July 24, 2013, the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2014 was passed in the House with a vote of 315-109. On October 22, 2013, the NDAA for FY2014 was introduced in the House, including provisions for defense counsel interviews of victims of sex-related offenses and regulations for handling sexual assault cases in the military. The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2014 and the NDAA for FY2014 included provisions for actions in response to protected communications regarding sexual assault, compliance tracking of commanding officers, advancement of report deadlines, retention of forms, access to Sexual Assault Response Coordinators, qualifications of personnel, commanding officer actions on reports, incident reporting requirements, and curricula for prevention of sexual assault in the military. The NDAA for FY2014 included provisions to address sexual assault in the military, with Title XVII focusing on prevention and response. Dr. Karen S. Guice testified on the relationship between sexual assault survivors and mental health issues. H.R. 4435, the NDAA for FY2015, was introduced in April 2014. The bill introduced in 2015 applied provisions from the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 to military service academies, consulted with sexual assault victims on prosecution preferences, created a review process for discharge terms, revised evidence retention policies, and required a review of separation procedures for assault reports. An amendment was rejected by the House Armed Services Committee before passing in the House. The House Armed Services Committee rejected an amendment from Congresswoman Speier to remove the military chain of command from prosecuting sexual assault cases. A proposal to only remove commanding officers' prosecutorial discretion for sexual assault cases was also rejected. The Carl Levin National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 was introduced in the Senate, including measures to enhance sexual assault prevention and response in the military. On December 19, 2014, H.R. 3979, the Carl Levin and Howard P. "Buck" McKeon National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015, was signed into law as P.L. 113-291. It included provisions under Subtitle D—Military Justice, addressing sexual assault and domestic violence prevention and response in the military. Key points covered included modifications to DOD policy on retention of evidence in sexual assault cases, requirements for Sexual Assault Forensic Examiners, analysis of serious offenses disposition, and the establishment of a Defense Advisory Committee on Investigation, Prosecution, and Defense of Sexual Assault in the Armed Forces. On January 13, 2015, S. 178, the Justice for Victims of Trafficking Act of 2015, was introduced in the Senate, including a provision for "Military Sex Offender Reporting" to the National Sex Offender Registry. It became P.L. 114-22 on May 29, 2015. H.R. 677, American Heroes COLA Act of 2015, passed in the House and referred to the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs. Section 6 prioritized veterans with claims related to military sexual trauma. H.R. 956, Military TRAC Act, introduced in the House to establish a sex offender registry for certain military offenses. H.R. 1735, National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016, introduced in April 2015. Subtitle D of H.R. 1735 and S. 1356 addressed military justice, including sexual assault and domestic violence prevention and response. Funding was allocated for the Sexual Assault Special Victims' Counsel Program in both bills. The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2016 introduced a policy to standardize training for Special Victims' Counsel and establish a Defense Advisory Committee on Investigation, Prosecution, and Defense of Sexual Assault in the Armed Forces. It also required the development of a plan to improve prevention and response to sexual assaults of male members of the Armed Forces, establish a strategy to prevent retaliation against members who report sexual assault, and authorized the President to modify Rule 304(c) of the Military Rules of Evidence. The bill introduced in the Senate on June 11, 2015 aimed to review discharges of individuals with mental health disorders from the Armed Forces. Another bill proposed in the Senate on the same day sought to reform procedures for court-martial determinations under the Uniform Code of Military Justice but did not pass. On April 12, 2016, H.R. 4909, the NDAA for FY2017, was introduced in the House and later passed. On April 18, 2016, H.R. 4991, the PROTECT Act of 2016, was introduced in the House to amend the Uniform Code of Military Justice. On May 18, 2016, S. 2943, the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017, was introduced in the Senate. Subtitle D of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 addressed review requirements for claims related to PTSD and TBI by former members. Subtitle E focused on sexual assault prevention and response efforts, including establishing evaluation metrics and modifying the definition of sexual harassment. Title XXXV established policies and training for sexual harassment and assault prevention at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. Title LIV and Title LX of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 addressed sexual offenses and accountability for sexual misconduct in the military. H.R. 5293, Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2017, was introduced in the House and passed on June 16, focusing on sexual assault prevention and response at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. The Senate received S. 3000, Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2017, which aimed to use O&M funds for the expansion of the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response (SAPR) Program. The bill was placed on the Senate Legislative Calendar and the Senate Committee on Appropriations held hearings on the matter. DOD Directives No. 6495.01 and 6495.02 outlined the SAPR Program. The DOD Directive No. 6495.02 outlines the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response (SAPR) Program procedures. It includes evaluations by the DOD Inspector General and reports from the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office (SAPRO) on sexual harassment and violence in the military. Annual reports from FY2004 to FY2016 and reports on the U.S. Military Service Academies are also included. The curr_chunk provides links to reports on sexual assault prevention and response programs at the United States Merchant Marine Academy and the United States Coast Guard. The reports include information on culture audits, biennial surveys, and military justice oversight related to sexual assault investigations. The curr_chunk provides links to reports on sexual assault prevention and response programs in the military, highlighting the need for better oversight and collaboration in investigations and adjudications. The curr_chunk lists reports on sexual assault prevention and response programs in the military, emphasizing the importance of improved oversight and collaboration in investigations and adjudications. The reports include information on hazing incidents involving servicemembers and ongoing news on military sexual assault from Military.com. The curr_chunk provides information on various reports and news articles related to the Lackland sex abuse scandal in the Air Force, including the identification of alleged victims, convictions of instructors for sex assaults, and the flood of sexual assault cases in military courts. Various reports and news articles related to the Lackland sex abuse scandal in the Air Force, including the identification of alleged victims, convictions of instructors for sex assaults, and the flood of sexual assault cases in military courts. Anne Mulrine, Patricia Kime, Ian Shapira, and Jennifer Steinhauer have all covered different aspects of the issue in their articles. Whitlock and Sisk report on the Pentagon grappling with sex crimes by military recruiters, with some in Congress calling for changes in military law as a result of the crisis. Dempsey suggests that the DOD may have become 'too forgiving' of such offenses. Several articles from various military publications discuss the issue of sexual assault in the military and the need for changes in military law. General Roger Brady comments on the risks of telling truths about sexual assault, while a senator calls for firing commanders allowing sex assault. An investigation into a sex assault case involving three football players at Annapolis is detailed, and there are efforts to temper military justice overhaul. U.S. lawmakers are taking action to limit military authority in sex assault cases. U.S. lawmakers are taking action to limit military authority in sex assault cases, with the House approving a 2-year jail term for military sex assault. The Senate is also involved in a complex fight over curbing military sexual assaults. Despite two decades of sexual assault in the military, there has been no real change in the message. Several articles discuss the issue of military sexual assault, highlighting the overlooked male victims, efforts to change the culture to combat rape, deficiencies in sex assault cases, and new support for the military in sex cases. Several articles discuss the issue of military sexual assault, highlighting efforts to change the culture to combat rape, deficiencies in sex assault cases, and new support for the military in sex cases. Several articles discuss the rise in incidents of military sexual assault, with reports showing a 46 percent increase. Military lawyers are facing changes as sexual assault gains more attention in the news. Men who have been sexually assaulted in the military are also speaking out about their experiences. Several articles discuss the rise in incidents of military sexual assault, with reports showing a 46 percent increase. Men who have been sexually assaulted in the military are also speaking out about their experiences. Documents reveal chaotic military sex-abuse record, with alcohol policies being reviewed as sex assault rises. Army knocks 2-star down to 1-star rank. Several articles discuss the increase in military sexual assault reports, with a focus on progress and challenges in addressing the issue. Male military sexual assault victims are highlighted as being slow to come forward, while sexual assault rates at military service academies have shown a decrease. Several articles discuss the increase in military sexual assault reports, with a focus on progress and challenges in addressing the issue. Sexual assault rates at military service academies have shown a decrease. The superintendents of federal service academies discuss their response to sexual assault issues. Military sexual assault claims result in jail time for 1 in 20 cases. Defense seeks dismissal of a sexual assault case transferred to Washington. The Defense Department proposes UCMJ changes to address sexual assault issues, while the Air Force launches a new strategy to curb sexual assault. Sexual assault reporting is on the rise. Sexual assault reporting has increased at U.S. service academies, with the Navy considering early separation for victims. Reports of sexual assault have spiked at the Naval Academy, West Point, and the Air Force Academy. The military is bringing more charges against officers for sexual assault. The military is bringing more charges against officers for sexual assault. Washington Post, March 20, 2016. Pentagon misled lawmakers on military sexual assault cases, Associated Press, April 18, 2016. Senators ask Obama to investigate Pentagon's sexual assault comments, The Hill, April 19, 2016. Air Force report on sexual assault progress, Air Force News, May 05, 2016. The military is facing challenges with sexual assault cases, with only 4 percent resulting in convictions. There are concerns about consent issues and the treatment of wrongly-discharged victims. Specialized support is being offered to sexual assault victims through the DoD Safe Helpline. Safe Helpline provides specialized support to sexual assault victims. Merchant Marine Academy faces criticism for sexual assault allegations. DoD unveils plan to broaden sexual assault support to men. Various sources discuss military sexual trauma. Various sources discuss military sexual trauma, including legal analysis of the Department of Defense report on sexual assault in the military, recommendations for care and policy following military sexual assault, and implications for criminal justice from gender relations and sexual harassment surveys. The curr_chunk discusses research on sexual assault and harassment in the military, including studies on victimization among women veterans and efforts to address the issue through training and workplace studies. The curr_chunk provides a list of research studies on sexual assault and harassment in the U.S. military, including estimates from the 2014 RAND Military Workplace Study and a review of policy and research trends. The curr_chunk lists congressional hearings related to sexual assault in the military, including testimonies and appropriations discussions. The curr_chunk provides details of various congressional hearings related to defense appropriations for fiscal year 2014, including discussions on President Obama's budget proposal for the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. The curr_chunk summarizes congressional hearings on defense appropriations for fiscal year 2014, including President Obama's budget proposal for the U.S. Army, Air Force, and Department of Defense. The curr_chunk provides a summary of congressional hearings on defense appropriations for fiscal year 2014, including discussions on the National Defense Authorization Act and Women in Service Reviews. The curr_chunk summarizes congressional hearings on defense appropriations for fiscal year 2014, including discussions on the National Defense Authorization Act and Women in Service Reviews. It includes details on budget requests from the Department of Defense, Department of the Navy, and Department of the Air Force. The curr_chunk provides details on budget requests from the Department of the Air Force for the fiscal year 2015, as discussed in congressional hearings. The curr_chunk summarizes congressional hearings on budget requests from the Department of the Air Force for fiscal year 2015. The curr_chunk provides details on Department of Defense Authorization for Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2016 and the Future Years Defense Program, including hearings by the Senate Armed Services Committee on various aspects of defense readiness and management support. The curr_chunk lists various congressional hearings related to defense authorization and appropriations for Fiscal Year 2016 and 2017, focusing on topics such as post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury research and treatment. The curr_chunk provides details of congressional hearings on defense authorization and appropriations for Fiscal Year 2016 and 2017, including topics like post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury research and treatment. The House Committee on Armed Services and Senate Committee on Armed Services issued reports on defense authorization and appropriations for Fiscal Year 2015, including the Howard P. "Buck" McKeon National Defense Authorization Act. The U.S. Congress issued various reports on defense appropriations and authorization bills for Fiscal Years 2015 and 2016. The U.S. Congress issued reports on defense appropriations and authorization bills for Fiscal Years 2015 and 2016, including bills for 2016 and 2017. The U.S. Congress issued reports on defense appropriations and authorization bills for Fiscal Years 2015 and 2016, including bills for 2016 and 2017. The reports include details on the Department of Defense Appropriations Bill for 2017, National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017, and related legislative sessions.
